Title: Lead Solution Architect, Data
Job_Description:
The Challenge:
Do you find yourself constantly looking for more and better information? Do you want a job where you can use your knowledge and research skills to improve national security? Never has the role of an all source analyst been so meaningful. More connected devices, larger storage capacity, and faster connections have resulted in an explosion of available information. The problem facing the intelligence community is no longer how to get more data – it’s understanding how to turn the data they have into answers. That’s where you come in. With critical thinking and flexibility, you quickly seek out accurate data sources, sift through the raw data and turn it into valuable intelligence. If you have strong analytical skills and a problem-solving mindset, we have an opportunity to use those skills to protect our national security.
As an all source analyst on our team, you’ll explore new data sources, create effective queries, and combine information from disparate sources to help your client understand their mission environment. You’ll learn how to validate the information and apply client tradecraft as you help build assessments for senior policymakers. This is a chance to grow your expertise in researching, drafting, and publishing time-sensitive threat assessments. You’ll develop new skills in classified and unclassified research and draft and publish intelligence assessments. Evaluate entities investing in US and Western technology and markets for threats to US national security. Understand technology and evaluate counterintelligence threats. Support and engage in continuing dialogue with analysts across the intelligence community (IC) and key personnel in the policy, military, and law enforcement communities on issues associated with foreign acquisitions and investment security. Work with analysts and supervisors at all levels and across several agencies to find and forge consensus on complex and frequently contentious issues. We focus on growing as a team to deliver the best support to our customers, so you’ll have resources for mentoring and learning new skills and tools. Join us as we provide the right information at the right time to support the critical needs of our policymakers.





Applicants selected will be subject to a security investigation and may need to meet eligibility requirements for access to classified information; TS/SCI clearance with polygraph is required.

JOB
The Portland Water Bureau is seeking an Analyst III to join the Hydroelectric Power Team. Are you self-motivated? Do you like dams and hydroelectric power? Do you like working in a collaborative team environment? If your answers are yes, you may be the Hydroelectric Power Analyst we are looking for. About the division: The Bureau of Hydroelectric Power (BHP) was established to manage the City’s Hydroelectric Power Production and Dam Safety Regulatory Programs. BHP is an independent City bureau that manages the daily operations of the City’s two separate hydroelectric powerhouses producing green energy for over 10,000 homes in the greater Portland metro area. The BHP's other critical mission is the execution and management of the City’s Dam Safety Program. BHP is responsible for the planning, execution, and reporting of the City’s dam safety program at both the State and Federal levels. BHP reports to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Oregon Water Resource Division to continually meet all the State and Federal licensing requirements. BHP manages its own annual operating budget of over $3 Million while ensuring for the entire range of technical, regulatory, business, and contractual responsibilities are fully executed for both programs. The BHP reports directly to the Water Bureau’s Engineering Services Group. About the position: The two-person BHP manages and operates the City’s Portland Hydroelectric Project (PHP), and is responsible for implementing the dam safety program for the Water Bureau’s five high-hazard potential dams: Bull Run Dams 1 and 2; and Mt. Tabor Dams 1, 5, and 6. The Bull Run Dams are among the City’s top liability risks, as their failure would result in potential loss of life, loss of a municipal water supply, property damage, and environmental damage. As a key member of the strategic team, you will be implementing the Water Bureau’s Dam Safety Program in accordance with current Federal and State engineering standards. This position seeks to effectively implement the Dam Safety Program for each of the complicated and structurally diverse City dam structures, requiring the utilization of professional engineering experience and expertise in relation to the program in a broad spectrum of civil engineering specialties, including hydraulics, hydrology, seismicity, geotechnical, foundation, soils, and structures. Duties and responsibilities include: Maintain and expand the City’s comprehensive dam safety program. You will assess the program; identify the training needs and develop and recommend external training areas to be incorporated into the program to train the PWB engineering and operations sections. Drafting and reviewing dam safety reports to ensure their accuracy, fullness, and regulatory compliance with engineering standards prior to submitting the final report to the FERC. Interact with The Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW) as it meets the City’s obligations for fish passage mitigation due to operations within the Bull Run Watershed. Reporting to many agencies including the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality for water rates within the Bull Run River; The Department of Energy for reporting yearly power production levels and water usage rates; The Western Electrical Coordination Council and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation for the proper scheduling and dispatching operations for power produced at the PHP. Plans, schedules, coordinates, and performs the annual PWB Emergency Action Plan drills and exercises both within the PWB and with outside agencies, including dam-brake evacuation and emergency planning and telephonic/digital notification to the public in downriver areas that would be impacted by a dam failure in the Bull Run River. You will help establish the curriculum, act as a liaison, and conduct and lead the annual dam safety training for both the Water Bureau employees and the affected contractors in the watershed. You will assist in the yearly independent contract execution reviews at the commercial, State, and Federal levels, accurately recording and generating all data, logs, and reports needed to support the BHPs yearly regulatory reporting requirements. Guide and facilitate the PWB’s reoccurring five-year, FERC-required, Part 12 independent consultants report for the high-hazard dams in the Bull Run reservation. Maintaining and updating a compilation of all engineering analyses and related information for the Bull Run Dams in a Supporting Technical Information Document for an independent engineering consultant to review and reference in an inspection report to ensure compliance with the FERC’s Engineering Guidelines. Analyze the independent consultant’s draft report for accuracy and compliance with engineering standards. Recommend acceptance of, or changes to, the draft report, as appropriate, prior to the submittal of a final report to the FERC. Assist the HPB to track and report reservoir and river level elevation control for both the FERC license and reporting to State Regulators in support of the Habitat Conservation Plan. Additionally, track and report electric power production and power use by the PHP. Plan/review/revise annually all programs to ensure that they meet the latest Federal requirements for operation and security. Assist in developing the yearly maintenance work plans for BHP's major contract with Energy Northwest (ENW), including the project timelines and scheduled plant outages. Assist with demonstrating the full compliance by the PHP for power generation and environmental regulatory compliance to the City’s regulatory licenses. As a person, you are: Collaborative: This job is highly collaborative, you will assist the BHP in producing and reviewing the City’s position for all hydroelectric programs, required reports, and studies that are regulatorily required by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), coordinate and oversee the yearly inspection(s) with FERC of the PHP Power Facilities and of PWB Dams 1 and 2 in the Bull Run Watershed. Strong Communicator: who can articulate dam safety and dam engineering designs and concepts to audiences from diverse educational and professional backgrounds. Analytical: you enjoy technically challenging work requiring both rigorous engineering analysis and hands-on interaction with a variety of infrastructures in differing operational environments. Equity Focused: You have experience placing an equity lens on the projects and can assist in the execution of the PHP Operations and Maintenance program and Capital Projects Improvement Plan in support of improving and maintaining the City’s complex hydropower infrastructure. BAE Systems is seeking an exceptional Systems Engineer for an exciting opportunity to support the Air Force's acquisition of the next generation Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) system, known as the Sentinel ICBM Program.

Without a doubt, Sentinel is one of the Department of Defense’s (DoD’s) most important acquisition efforts for the next decade, if not longer. To find out more about how you can grow your career at UC Berkeley, visit grow.berkeley.edu .

Departmental Overview

Standing nearly on top of the Hayward Fault, the Berkeley Seismological Laboratory (BSL) provides robust hazard information while engaging in essential geophysical research. Throughout the BSL's long history of innovation , beginning with the 1897 installation of the first seismograph in the western hemisphere, our commitment to probing the Earth's deepest secrets has remained unchanged.

Today, the BSL operates several different networks and has expanded into a broader range of geophysical monitoring. Data from these geophysical networks are recorded digitally and are archived at the Northern California Earthquake Data Center, which is located at the Berkeley Seismological Lab. Researchers from around the world use data from the BSL. In addition to their use in earthquake studies, these data are useful for rapid notification of earthquakes. Together with the USGS Menlo Park, the Berkeley Seismological Laboratory reports earthquake information within a few minutes of occurrence. Our lab also acts as part of a statewide earthquake monitoring system, the California Integrated Seismic Network.

BSL operates a network of geophysical observatories throughout Northern California and Southern Oregon. These seismic or geodetic observatories send near real time data to our datacenters and are used for research purposes and a new earthquake early warning system called "ShakeAlert".

This position involves professional engineering and engineering technician support as part of academic instructional lab and/or research projects and programs. Engineering activities include the design, construction, testing of experimental systems, operation of analytical systems, establishment of performance specifications, and documentation. Engineering Technicians may be assigned duties within a single discipline (e.g., electrical) or span a range of disciplines [Note: for machine specialty work in a research or lab setting, see Research and Laboratory Job Field, Lab Mechanician Job Family].

1) Be involved in the locating, planning, permitting, construction, installation and maintenance of new and existing observatories; 2) Ensure that produced data is being telemetered property and data meets quality specifications; 3) troubleshoot and repair complex issues at remote observatories.

This position involves supporting research efforts within the department and partner agencies. Activities span a wide range of disciplines, including but not limited to, power systems, analog and digital circuits, construction & fabrication, computer networking, planning, and documenting. A working knowledge of Windows, Mac, Unix, and Linux operating systems is desirable. These task are done under the supervision of management and/or senior engineers.

Many tasks are expected to be completed with little or no support or supervision in very remote settings. Work is often performed in extreme conditions such as rain, snow, heat, cold, high winds, etc. The position involves overnight travel up to 50% of the time.

Some remote sites utilize a private microwave radio system to telemeter data. Repairing this equipment often requires work at remote radio tower sites. This position involves climbing radio towers to remove and replace equipment. The employee will be trained and certified and appropriate equipment will be provided.

BSL Employees routinely interact with the public and are required to exhibit a high level of professionalism and judgement. This includes interfacing with public and private property owner and various stakeholders in the public and private sectors.
